Award.AwardTitle: PULSE OF THE PLANET'S CHILDREN'S SCIENCE CHALLENGE

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Division.LongName: Div Of Elem Secondary & Informal Sci Ed

Award.AbstractNarration: This project would create radio programs, podcasts, Internet blogs, and other materials to engage children 8-11 years old. Using science challenge competitions, radio broadcasts and interactive web features, this project will showcase children's interactions with scientists and engineers. To reinforce involvement, the project will develop and distribute scientist trading cards, science activity books and other products directly linked to project themes. Project deliverables include 150 Pulse of the Planet radio programs which focus on the interaction between a select group of scientists and youths 8-11, who have been chosen from a nationwide Science Challenge which encourages children to submit questions and potential experiments to scientists; 60 podcasts designed for children; onsite visits by children and parents to science labs and research sites; and website features including podcasts, scientist blogs, and related projects and activities. Project partners include a variety of businesses (e.g., sports manufacturers such as K2), media (e.g., internet social networks such as imbee.com, TIME for Kids, Dragonfly TV, and Hispanic Communications Network) and educational partnerships (e.g. Community Science Workshops and the National Science Teacher's Association.) Underserved participants will be reached through Celebra la Ciencia science outreach programs. The evaluator, Knight-Williams, will carry out formative evaluation to inform the design of the radio programs and learning resources. The summative evaluation will explore how children interact with and learn from listening to the podcasts, getting and using the activity book, pursuing information on the Internet, joining the imbee.com online community and engaging with teachers or parents while doing these activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
After a year of preparation, the Kids' Science Challenge, (KSC) launched in October, 2008 on kidsciencechallenge.com.  The KSC is a free nationwide competition for third to sixth graders. This age group marks a critical time in the life of a youngster, when they're relatively open to new ideas.  It's also a demographic reached by few other science competitions. The aim of the KSC is to attract and engage our target audience in the worl of science, particularly those not already in the science camp.  We offered kid-friendly challenges each year on kidsciencechallenge.com, supported by a suite of resources, including videos, games, curricula, activities and online chats with scientists.  Challenge examples: design a package that won't end up in a landfill; devise a new kind of musical instrument; invent something inspired by the world of nature. Kids entered with parental approval by submitting an idea responding to the challenge, with an optional drawing and a description of how they came up with the idea.  Winners visited and collaborated with scientists to see their idea come alive.  Each year, the first thousand KSC entrants were mailed a free hands-on activity kit. The kits were newly developed each year, corresponding to that year's science topics.

  In four seasons of the KSC, 5157 kids entered from 44 states.  165 Pulse of the Planet radio programs were broadcast which featured KSC scientists and winners.  Pulse reaches an audience of 1,000,000 adults each week over 185 broadcast outlets.  Over 3000 educators downloaded KSC curricula and 1100 parents joined the KSC mailing list. Over a year, kidsciencechallenge.com and pulseplanet.com received 3,820,700 pages views averaging over 10,000 page views daily; 1,003,400 sessions, averaging 2741  sessions daily (average session length 5:48).

  Kids entered the competition as individuals and teams.  Entries were received from individuals, classes, homeschoolers, Girl Scouts, 4-H and afterschool groups.  Each year, we presented hand-on science activity workshops at a number of venues, including the Cambridge Science Festival, Yuri's Night, the LA Girl Scouts Family Science Day, and Maker Faire, interadting with thousands of kids and parents.

  KSC partners included Whyville, WoogiWorld (kids social networks),  Sustainable Packaging Coalition,  Biomimicry Institute,  Portland Zoo and Syracuse University.

  Kidsciencechallenge.com received a Parent's Choice Award.  KSC winners have been featured on the Today Show, NPR's Science Friday and Morning Edition, the Washington Post, Time Magazine for Kids, Earth Magazine, Ranger Rick and thousands of blogs and 'zines.

 We created a brainstorming tool, an online "cloud" of activities and videos designed to jumpstart new ideas. We provided mentor guidelines to train facilitators working with individuals and teams to come up with ideas for the KSC.  We offered guidelines for educators to use KSC entries as starting points for science fair projects, and a scavenger hunt where kids search through online content  to find clues to a series of questions.

The KSC model proved that a competition works well as an incentive for engaging kids in science.
